headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Regina, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Apache Corporation First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the c
componenttext:
Good afternoon. My name is Regina, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Apache Corporation First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Gary Clark, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us on Apache Corporation's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Speakers making prepared remarks on today's call will be Apache's CEO and President, John Christmann; and CFO, Steve Riney. Also joining us
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us on Apache Corporation's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. 
Speakers making prepared remarks on today's call will be Apache's CEO and President, John Christmann; and CFO, Steve Riney. Also joining us in the room is Tim Sullivan, Executive Vice President of Operations. 
In conjunction with this morning's press release, I hope you have had the opportunity to review our quarterly earnings supplement, which summarizes key financial and operational data for the first quarter, along with details regarding our updated 2016 production outlook. Our earnings release and quarterly earnings supplement can be found on our website at www.apachecorp.com/financials-reporting.aspx. 
I'd like to remind everyone that today's discussions will contain forward-looking estimates and assumptions based on our current views and reasonable expectations. However, a number of factors could cause actual results could differ materially from what we discussed today. A full disclaimer is located with the supplemental data on our website. 
I will now turn the call over to John.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gary. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. In the first quarter, Apache delivered solid operational results, strong financial performance and notable drilling outcomes, all of which were supported by our relentless focus on continuou
componenttext:
Thank you, Gary. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. 
In the first quarter, Apache delivered solid operational results, strong financial performance and notable drilling outcomes, all of which were supported by our relentless focus on continuous improvement and cost reductions. 
Today, I would like to start with a brief recap of first quarter results and an update to Apache's 2016 production guidance. I will then provide an operational overview with particular emphasis on some of the exceptional well cost reductions we're achieving on our key North American onshore plays. I will conclude with thoughts on our current activity levels and the potential for increasing capital investment in the near future. 
As noted in this morning's press release, company-wide pro forma production of 479,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day was at the high-end of our currently guidance range of 470,000 to 480,000 BOEs per day. The outperformance came primarily from North American Onshore, which produced 298,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, and exceeded our 290,000 to 295,000 BOE per day guidance range. Each other Apache's North American operating areas performed well despite a significant reduction in capital. 
The Permian, in particular, delivered robust results with strong performance from the underlying base, coupled with solid contributions from both newly drilled wells and base maintenance projects. In light of first quarter productions strength, we are raising our full year 2016 North American Onshore guidance range by 5,000 BOEs per day to 268,000 to 278,000 BOEs per day. 
On International and Offshore side, pro forma production was 180,000 BOEs per day, which was at the low end of our guidance range of 180,000 to 185,000 BOEs per day. This primarily attributable to unplanned third-party plant and pipeline outages in the North Sea. We remain on track to achieve our full year 2016 international and offshore guidance of 170,000 to 180,000 BOEs per day. 
As we've stated previously, our 2016 North American Onshore drilling program is primarily focused on strategic testing and acreage delineation to building high-grade inventory. Nevertheless, we are continuing to see some remarkable progress on growing efficiencies. 
For example, in key areas of North America where Apache was actively drilling during the first quarter, the average drilled and completed well costs were down approximately 45% as compared to average well cost in 2014. On the expense side, continuing with our efforts from last year, we saw further reductions in both lease operating expenses and gross G&A. Looking ahead, we anticipate further benefits from aligning our cost with the scale of our business and the commodity price environment. 
As you will recall, Apache is targeting cash flow neutrality in 2016 under our current budget, which assumes flat $35 oil and 2 35 gas. As expected, we were not cash flow neutral in the first quarter. However, we do anticipate generating a net cash flow surplus to the remainder of the year. As such, we remain on track for unchanged or lower net debt levels at year-end. Steve Riney will elaborate further on this in his prepared remarks. 
With the recent improvements in strip oil prices, we are prepared to increase capital spending but will refrain until we're confident cash flow sustainably improved relative to our 2016 plan. Although we have the financial capacity to increase capital spending today, we believe that preserving our strong financial position and our quality through cash flow neutrality is the best approach for our shareholders in this price environment. I will provide more color on our thinking around this in a few minutes. 
Turning to our operations. In the Permian Basin, first quarter production held up well despite a significant decrease in the number of wells placed on production. We produced 171,000 BOE per day, which represents a 2% sequential decrease from the fourth quarter. In the Delaware, we placed 5 gross operated wells on production, primarily targeting Bone Springs formation in the Pecos Bend area. One very notable well, the Seagull 103 HR produced an exceptional 30-day average peak rate of nearly 2,800 barrels of oil equivalent per day from a lateral length of approximately 4,600 feet. In its first 60 days of production, the Seagull 103 HR accumulated 78,000 barrels of oil, which makes it Apache's best well today in the Delaware Basin. The success of the Seagull 103-HR is a function of our thorough understanding of the hydrocarbon system and continuous efforts to improve our results in these complex reservoirs. 
Thus far, our efforts in the Pecos Bend area at the Delaware have been focused on 2 primary landing zones in the 3rd Bone Spring formation: During the first quarter, we test a promising new landing zone within the 3rd Bone Spring that could significantly enhance our running room in the area. In the Midland Basin, Central Basin Platform and Northwest Shelf, we placed 25 gross operated wells on production, which is approximately 40% fewer wells than in the fourth quarter. During the first quarter, Apache generated good results from 6 Wolfcamp wells in the Powell area, 2 Wolfcamp completions at Wildfire and 4 horizontal Yeso wells on the Northwest Shelf, all of which are summarized in our quarterly earnings supplement. 
Before moving on to Egypt and the North Sea, I would like to highlight our North American well cost-reduction efforts, which continue to exceed our expectations. Last quarter, I noted that we have dedicated a considerable amount of time, energy and resources toward reinvigorating Apache's strong culture of costs and returns discipline. This quarter, we are seeing some very tangible result from these initiatives, which I would like to share with you. 
As I mentioned earlier, in key areas of North America where Apache is actively drilling, our average drilled and completed well costs were down approximately 45% in the first quarter compared to average 2014 levels. Notably, in the Delaware Basin, our most recent well cost were now down approximately 60%. Although we have made great strides throughout 2015, I am truly amazed by the ongoing positive cost trends on North American onshore of drilling program. 6 quarters into the downturn, we are still achieving significant quarter-on-quarter cost improvements. For example, in the Delaware Basin, we recently drilled and completed a Third Bone spring well for $3.5 million. In the Midland Basin, 1-mile horizontal Wolfcamp and 1.5 mile Lower Spraberry drilling and completion costs are now projected to be less than $4 million and $4.5 million, respectively. In the horizontal Yeso play, on the Northwest Shelf in the Permian, recent well cost are trending below $2.3 million. And in the Woodford/SCOOP, our latest pacesetter well was drilled and completed for only $6.6 million. Achieving these lower well costs, both expands our drillable inventory and significantly enhances our returns for future development programs. 
Recently, we have received questions about the sustainability of our well cost improvements once demand for oilfield services begins to rebound. The high-level answer is that more than 50% of our average well cost decreased since the 2014 peak has come from design and efficiency improvements and should, therefore, be viewed as permanent cost saves. 
In our earnings supplement of this quarter, we have provided exhibits for our key North American Onshore plays that highlight the breakdown between service price and efficiency improvements. 
Apache's cost achievements to date are more than just belt-tightening efforts in response to the downturn. We seek to continuously implement structural changes and improvements, which accrue to the bottom line and enhance our long-term returns regardless of where oil prices and service cost close in the future. 
Now turning to our international operations. In the North Sea, first quarter production was slightly above 70,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, which represents a 2% decline sequentially from the fourth quarter of 2015. Unplanned downtime, associated with outages, on the third-party operated pipeline system negatively impacted our sales volumes by approximately 1,700 BOEs per day during the quarter. These averages reduced our production uptime from what would have been 94% down to 90%. As a reminder, U.K. North Sea industry average production uptime has been between 60% and 70% over the last several years. Therefore, Apache maintains a significant competitive advantage in this regard. Despite the higher-than-expected downtime during the quarter, Apache still achieved exceptional LOE cost of approximately $11 per BOE. 
Our first quarter development drilling program in the North Sea delivered 4 successful new wells, all of which were placed online in the second half of the quarter. This set up strong product rebound during the month of April. The nature of the North Sea operations and production is such that they're always be monthly and quarterly lumpiness, but we are confident in our full year 2016 production guidance, which we stated would decline slightly year-over-year from 2015 levels. 
Our subsea tieback of the Callater discovery is proceeding on-time and on budget, and we continued to expect this project will begin production in the 2017. We're also looking forward to drilling our store and Corona expiration prospects, which we highlighted in our North Sea webcast last November. 
In Egypt, our gross production of approximately 353,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day was essentially flat with the fourth quarter. Steve will provide more color on Egypt production reporting in a few minutes, but excluding tax barrels and the [indiscernible] interest, pro forma production in Egypt was up slightly versus the fourth quarter. 
Apache's drilling program in Egypt continues to deliver successful and reliable results. We placed 23 wells on production during the first quarter and achieved a drilling success rate of 88%, which is in line with our historical success rates in Egypt. 
At our prolific Ptah and Berenice deals, we placed 2 more wells on production, bringing the total level of producing wells in the complex to 13. We have a few additional locations remaining to fully develop Ptah and Berenice, but facilities are currently constrained. 
Before I move on, I would like to leave you with a few high-level observations on Egypt. Apache's operation in Egypt remains stable. Our drilling work over and water flood programs continue to deliver quarter-after-quarter. When compared to North America, our well costs were relatively low and our netbacks and margins are relatively high. And lastly, cash flow generation in Egypt demonstrates much less price-related volatility the North America despite reported net production volatility from quarter-to-quarter. As we all contemplate the timing and magnitude of an oil price recovery, I want to leave you with a few key points around our thinking with regard to 2016 capital spending and the potential for incremental activity above our current plan. Cash flow is the governor of Apache's capital spending and activity levels in 2016. We still plan to manage cash flow neutrality, and exit the year with unchanged or lower net debt levels. We entered 2016 with an industry cost structure that was still out of sync with the low oil price environment. The recent rally in oil prices, coupled with our cost reductions, means that development drilling in North America is now generating acceptable returns in many areas. We believe these returns will continue to improve as cost come into better alignment with price. Recent improvements in oil prices are encouraging. We're now looking for a sustainably improved pricing structure that will generate the cash flow visibility for us to confidently increase our capital program. The potential timing and magnitude of this increase is the topic of significant planning and discussion right now at Apache and with our board. In the meantime, the vast majority of Apache North American Onshore spending is focused on target testing, acreage evaluation and expanding our low-cost inventory locations to be exported environment that offers higher returns. When the time is appropriate, our first priority is for increased investment will be to add development rigs in the Permian, we will also accelerate North American acreage testing and we will keep our 2 platform rigs running in the North Sea. Beyond that, the Woodford/SCOOP play and Egypt are next in line for incremental capital. Importantly, Apache has maintained the organizational capacity and personnel to operate a significantly higher number of rigs, and we're well prepared to ramp up activity when appropriate. Lastly, we are very mindful of the fact that we're in a highly cyclical and highly capital-intensive business. As such, any ramp in investment activity will pass rigorous hurdles on returns and net present value. 
In closing, Apache's portfolio and capital allocation approach is designed to withstand volatility over the long term, which is evident in our results. We look forward to demonstrating the capability of our North American assets and efficiency of our capital allocation process in the next upturn. 
I want to reiterate what I said at our last quarter's earnings call. Our plan is to emerge from this commodity price downturn with top-tier financial strength, a robust inventory of higher drilling opportunities and a sustained capacity to generate free cash flow from our international assets in Egypt and the North Sea. We have made great progress in these efforts. 
Over the long term, our goal is to offer a competitive debt adjusted per share production reserve and cash flow growth rates and to achieve a top quartile cost position in terms of average well cost, G&A and LOE per BOE. We will accomplish this with an intense focus on long-term full cycle returns for our investment programs. Through the cycle, we believe this will translate into significantly improved returns and appreciation in our share price. 
I will now turn the call over to Steve Riney.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John, and good afternoon. In addition to reviewing our financial results for the first quarter of 2016, I would like to highlight our progress on several key financial objectives. These include: Continuing to aggressively drive down well cost l
componenttext:
Thank you, John, and good afternoon. In addition to reviewing our financial results for the first quarter of 2016, I would like to highlight our progress on several key financial objectives. These include: Continuing to aggressively drive down well cost lease, operating expense and G&A; achieving cash flow neutrality inclusive of dividends under our flat $35 oil price; protecting our strong liquidity and financial position; and ending the year with unchanged or reduced net debt.  Additionally, I will speak to our 2016 outlook for capital spending, LOE and G&A. And finally, I would like to review Egypt production volume reporting to address some potential confusion about the difference between reported volumes and the pro forma volumes we typically reference. 
So let's begin with the first quarter financial results. As noted in our press release, under generally accepted accounting principles, Apache reported a loss of $489 million or $1.29 per common share. Our results for the quarter include a number of items outside of our core earnings and are typically excluded by the investment community in published earnings estimates. The most significant of which are ceiling test write-downs. These items totaled $337 million after-tax in the first quarter. And as in prior prudes, resulted primarily from the continued low commodity price environment. Our loss for the quarter, adjusted for these items, was $152 million or $0.40 per diluted share. As John mentioned, better-than-expected onshore North America production and solid operating cost performance worldwide were key contributors to our first quarter 2016 financial results. Apache's continuing focus on driving cost efficiencies resulted in capital spending of $466 million during the first quarter, which excludes noncontrolling interest. This is well below our guidance range of $500 million to $550 million. Capital cost in all of our North American regions were lower than we budgeted, with Permian leading the way. Our capital spending guidance of $1.4 billion to $1.8 billion for the full year 2016 remains unchanged. We are clearly achieving better-than-expected capital efficiency, thus, absent an increase in planned activity, I would expect us to end the year somewhere in the bottom half of this range. That said, if the current oil price environment prevails, it is more likely that we will maintain or even increase drilling and completion activity from current levels, which would result in increased capital spending. 
Lease operating expenses in the first quarter were $7.81 per barrel of oil equivalent, 22% lower than the fourth quarter of 2015. Underlying improvement in this metric is primarily attributable to greater efficiency in North American onshore production and the timing of workovers and other expenditures in the Permian and North Sea. While we are very pleased with this cost performance, certain one-time items and timing issues benefited us in a way that will not continue through the year. 
Last quarter, we've provided guidance that full year 2016 LOE per BOE would be roughly flat compared to full year 2015. This implied a target of approximately $9.50 per BOE. With the progress we have already seen this year, we now believe 2016 LOE will be closer to $9.25 per BOE. 
On the G&A side, total cost continue to decline as we remain diligently focused on aligning overhead with capital spending levels. Our goal for the year was to further reduce gross cash overhead cost to a range of $650 million to $700 million. We are currently tracking toward the low end of this range, and we continue finding opportunities to further reduce these costs. 
In the first quarter of 2016, recurring DD&A was $11.42 per BOE, 34% lower than the fourth quarter of 2015. Our DD&A cost over the last several quarters have been on a clear downward trend as a result of price-related asset write-downs. 
Lastly, on cost, we incurred $90 million of net interest expense in the first quarter. You will note a trend of increasing expense interest and decreasing capitalized interest over the last several quarters. This is a result of unproved property impairments and reduced capital investment activity. 
Next, I would like to make a few comments regarding our financial strength and liquidity position. In 2015, we worked very hard to strengthen our financial position and maintain our investment-grade credit rating with the 3 primary rating agencies. Having accomplished this, one of our key financial objective is to protect this position by maintaining unchanged or even reduced net debt by year end 2016. 
During the first quarter, cash uses exceeded sources by approximately $463 million. This was primarily the result of commodity realizations coming in below our plan, our front-end loaded capital program, and a build in working capital due to the timing of some nonrecurring working capital items. We anticipated these negative impacts early in the year will be more than offset later in the year. 
Even with the shortfall in first quarter cash flows, we ended the quarter with approximately $1 billion in cash.  In summary, our financial condition and liquidity remain very strong. We have created this position through disciplined capital spending and aggressive cost management rather than issuing equity, reducing the dividend or selling core assets. Importantly, we still have good visibility to cash flow neutrality of our $35 planned level. 
Finally, I would like to take a moment to discuss Egypt production volume reporting. As you're aware, we most often refer you to pro forma production volumes, which, for Egypt, excludes 2 items: The 1/3 minority share of volumes attributable to our partner; and tax barrels. Throughout 2014, and the first 3 quarters of 2015, our reported tax barrel production averaged approximately 26,500 barrels of oil equivalent per day. Asset impairments in the fourth quarter of 2015 and in the first quarter of 2016, combined with low oil prices, created a significant amount of noise in these tax barrel volumes. In the fourth quarter of 2015, these items resulted in negative tax barrel reported production of 47,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. In the first quarter of 2016, they resulted in Apache recording only 1,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day of production. As a reminder, tax barrels have no economic effect on our net cash flow from the business. Combined with the fact that they lead to this type of recording volatility, we believe investors should focus primarily on pro forma production in Egypt. A more thorough description of this will be on our website, along with a brief history of the difference between Egypt reported and pro forma volumes. We have also included this information for your reference in this quarter's earnings supplement. 
In closing, we took great efforts over the past 18 months to position Apache prudently for a prolonged downturn. After successfully navigating the challenges that confronted the industry in 2015, Apache is well prepared to capitalize on the opportunities that we believe will ultimately emerge. We have delivered a strong start to 2016 and look forward to continued progress throughout the year. Our primary goals for 2016 remain unchanged: We will live within our means; maintain our strong financial position; continue to build high-quality development inventory for the future; and invest to improve long-term returns and add shareholder value. While we remain conservative in our budgeting and planned activity, we are prepared to respond when the environment is right to increase investment. 
I would now like to turn the call over to the operator for Q&A.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ed Westlake with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ed Westlake with Credit Suisse.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quick question on cash. You [indiscernible] $1 billion of cash on the balance sheet. So I'm just wondering what's the optimal level? I mean, obviously peers have done some of the things Yeso said, like issue equity and sell assets to get their cash balanc
componenttext: Quick question on cash. You [indiscernible] $1 billion of cash on the balance sheet. So I'm just wondering what's the optimal level? I mean, obviously peers have done some of the things Yeso said, like issue equity and sell assets to get their cash balances high, and people expect the oil prices may still be low volatile.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Ed. This is Steve. I think at this point in time, I don't know what the optimal amount of cash on the balance sheet is. But I kind of like at this point in time, having $1 billion of cash on the balance sheet. It's good for liquidity, I think
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Ed. This is Steve. I think at this point in time, I don't know what the optimal amount of cash on the balance sheet is. But I kind of like at this point in time, having $1 billion of cash on the balance sheet. It's good for liquidity, I think that's a good time to have liquidity. It's a good time to have the cash ready for deployment, either in terms of paying down debt, if we decide we need to do that, or for deployment into the capital program if we see the price scenario in the future improving. Or for that matter, I'm happy just to hold cash. We do believe the cash balance will go back up to $1.5 billion by the end of this year based on our plan for the year.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, the ROC [ph] across the broad North American portfolio of other assets, which potentially may be of interest to others and as commodity prices lift ahead a little bit. Are you looking to do -- be more aggressive on perhaps disposals of Tier 2?
componenttext: I guess, the ROC [ph] across the broad North American portfolio of other assets, which potentially may be of interest to others and as commodity prices lift ahead a little bit. Are you looking to do -- be more aggressive on perhaps disposals of Tier 2?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The answer to that is we're always looking at the portfolio. We have done some small one-offs that are not really material to production. But at this point, we're always looking at our internal assets. We grade those against other things. We look at what
componenttext: The answer to that is we're always looking at the portfolio. We have done some small one-offs that are not really material to production. But at this point, we're always looking at our internal assets. We grade those against other things. We look at what could be added, and what would add incremental value. But right now, it's pretty hard litmus test because of the types of projects we deferred. So we see it on the pretty good set of assets, I really good inventory that they're very excited about. And we look out to improve it going forward. But nothing major planned on either side.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of David Tameron with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of David Tameron with Wells Fargo.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, David. I mean, that is one of the areas that we've got inventory that we could put back to work. I mean, right now we do not have a rig that's over there. We've drilled some fantastic wells with were cost structure moving now when pricing th
componenttext: Well, thanks, David. I mean, that is one of the areas that we've got inventory that we could put back to work. I mean, right now we do not have a rig that's over there. We've drilled some fantastic wells with were cost structure moving now when pricing that will be one of the areas that we could do add some future activity to. But right now, we don't have anything immediately planned to do, but we've got a lot of nice inventory.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as a follow-up. Bigger picture, if I think about last, last conference call, you made a comment that you could have kept [indiscernible] production flat at 45. Obviously, I think your service cost and efficiencies have improved since then.
componenttext: Okay. And then as a follow-up. Bigger picture, if I think about last, last conference call, you made a comment that you could have kept [indiscernible] production flat at 45. Obviously, I think your service cost and efficiencies have improved since then. Can you talk about looking forward, either give us an apples-to-apples summary for '16? Or what kind of project in the for, for '17, kind of what that range you look like?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll take you back to what I said on the last call, was in '16, another $900 million, which would have put our capital budget midpoint around 2.5, would have kept us flat in '16. As we look at '17, clearly, we continue to make progress on the effici
componenttext: Well, I'll take you back to what I said on the last call, was in '16, another $900 million, which would have put our capital budget midpoint around 2.5, would have kept us flat in '16. As we look at '17, clearly, we continue to make progress on the efficiency side, which would lower that. Our decline on our base is flattening, it's a function of -- we're now 18 months into a slowdown in terms of the numbers of wells have the bring on, so that helps. Plus the base rate is a lower that we've got to keep flat. So we see clearly, less capital in '17 to keep it flat there, but it's got to look moving targeted at this point. And obviously, the other factor is the got some projects that we're advancing. Callater in the North Sea is on track, which will give us a big kick in the middle of '17. So it's going to be less, but it's pretty dynamic and we're in the middle of working through the planning process at this point. So at this point, I'll just say it's got to be less than it would have been this year, and you're right, $900 million were $45 base planned versus our $35 would have kept us neutral in '16, but that will be a lower number for '17.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Pearce Hammond from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Pearce Hammond from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question, John. What is driving the steep decline in LOE? And then how sustainable are those cost declines?
componenttext: My first question, John. What is driving the steep decline in LOE? And then how sustainable are those cost declines?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, and I'd let Steve chime in, in a minute. A lot of it is timing and how things came up in the first quarter. We had a big drop in a couple of areas. It is not something that will be there for the rest of the year, which is kind of where we moved our
componenttext: Well, and I'd let Steve chime in, in a minute. A lot of it is timing and how things came up in the first quarter. We had a big drop in a couple of areas. It is not something that will be there for the rest of the year, which is kind of where we moved our numbers down from 9 50 guidance to about $9.25. But we're making progress, and I've got confidence the guys can keep working on those numbers.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just echoing John's comments. We had good cost results in Egypt, in Permian and North Sea, all 3 of them are very strong. I think there's a good mix of that, just timing related, and you will note that kind of a reduction doesn't show up in the guida
componenttext: Yes, just echoing John's comments. We had good cost results in Egypt, in Permian and North Sea, all 3 of them are very strong. I think there's a good mix of that, just timing related, and you will note that kind of a reduction doesn't show up in the guidance reduction to $9.25 per BOE.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you. And then my follow-up is given the improvement in commodity price, any updated thoughts on hedging?
componenttext: Great. Thank you. And then my follow-up is given the improvement in commodity price, any updated thoughts on hedging?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this point, the environment's getting much better. I mean, we like the direction on the cost. We like the direction on the oil price. So I think we're at the point where things are starting to look pretty darn attractive. But right now, our best head i
componenttext: At this point, the environment's getting much better. I mean, we like the direction on the cost. We like the direction on the oil price. So I think we're at the point where things are starting to look pretty darn attractive. But right now, our best head is we haven't committed to a lot of rigs or big program at this point. So it's one of the things we will be discussing at the start to look at plans. But at this point, we're not quite feel good about locking in a scenario.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to make sure I understand the activity reacceleration, which sounds closer. You accelerated around current levels, or are you looking for market fundamentals to clean up and then that acceleration will be governed that pace of acceleration wil
componenttext: I just want to make sure I understand the activity reacceleration, which sounds closer. You accelerated around current levels, or are you looking for market fundamentals to clean up and then that acceleration will be governed that pace of acceleration will be governed to remain cash flow neutral? Is that right?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the case that we budgeted to be cash flow neutral this year at $35 and that $2.35 gas price. We're a little bit behind that in the first quarter on oil. We're behind it on gas. Clearly, in April, we've seen a little bit of a rebound. So if t
componenttext: Well, I think the case that we budgeted to be cash flow neutral this year at $35 and that $2.35 gas price. We're a little bit behind that in the first quarter on oil. We're behind it on gas. Clearly, in April, we've seen a little bit of a rebound. So if the strip were to hold up, clearly, we're going to be in a position to have some cash to deploy in the back half of the year, and those are the types of things we would look at. But there's lots of things right there. I mean, we could than that, that we could address or new program. But the plan would be to cash flow is going to be the governor. We plan to stay cash neutral. And we'll have some options to choose from if the current conditions hold.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. You also discussed your North American capital allocation into recovery, but you didn't mention the Eagle Ford, which I thought was a higher hurdle from your previous comments. Again, in 1Q, you completed 4 Eagle Ford wells with competitive results
componenttext: Great. You also discussed your North American capital allocation into recovery, but you didn't mention the Eagle Ford, which I thought was a higher hurdle from your previous comments. Again, in 1Q, you completed 4 Eagle Ford wells with competitive results. Can you discuss what the driver there was, was that some signs or lease-related activity?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we mentioned we've been doing a lot of strategic testing. I mean, most of our North American capital is designed to that. We have some wells that were down that we wanted to complete and be able to evaluate those. The Eagle Ford will require a littl
componenttext: Well, we mentioned we've been doing a lot of strategic testing. I mean, most of our North American capital is designed to that. We have some wells that were down that we wanted to complete and be able to evaluate those. The Eagle Ford will require a little higher hurdle than some of the others plays so as we start to think about in the future participant put capital back to work. Right now, it would not be the first plays it would go. But we're seeing great progress in the Eagle Ford as well. And have made a lot of progress over the last 18 months. So it's something I think can be an option in the future.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Herrlin from Societe Generale.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Herrlin from Societe Generale.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a question for shales. Obviously, you've had a lot of improvement. How much capital are you really dedicate from the science side of things to better optimize studies, densities, things like that?
componenttext: I have a question for shales. Obviously, you've had a lot of improvement. How much capital are you really dedicate from the science side of things to better optimize studies, densities, things like that?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I'd say if you look at our strategic testing, it really falls in the several buckets. And I don't have an exact on how much it is in that portion of it. But we're doing 3 things really. I mean, we're testing the acreage, we're testing the zones, and
componenttext: John, I'd say if you look at our strategic testing, it really falls in the several buckets. And I don't have an exact on how much it is in that portion of it. But we're doing 3 things really. I mean, we're testing the acreage, we're testing the zones, and then we're optimizing within zones. And then if you look at our completions in a lot of the Permian as well as the Woodford or even in Eagle Ford, I mean, we're taking and integrating seismic data, core data, Pedro physics, landing zones, everything. And as we're doing a lot of time on that anything that you're seeing some of the productivity things that are showing up from that time that we're taking to do things properly, and we've learned an awful lot.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Next one for me. With the services companies, do you find that your conversations about future activity levels and costs are different? Is it more collegial, less adversarial?
componenttext: Okay. Next one for me. With the services companies, do you find that your conversations about future activity levels and costs are different? Is it more collegial, less adversarial?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say that really since the fall of last year, it's become a lot more collaborative. I mean, we've had some really good sitdown discussions with some of the small service companies as well as some of the very big ones. And I've met some really
componenttext: Yes, I would say that really since the fall of last year, it's become a lot more collaborative. I mean, we've had some really good sitdown discussions with some of the small service companies as well as some of the very big ones. And I've met some really early constructive conversations on how do we lower the cost structure in North America. And a lot of progress on that front. I think our willingness to recognize that, that is what it's going to take going forward, and you see in some of the fruits show up. Not just in terms of cost reductions from the server-side but in terms of executions, efficiencies, structural things, a lot of these things that are going to be permanent. And that's what's important.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Arun Jayaram with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Arun Jayaram with JPMorgan.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I was wondering if you could perhaps comment on some of the steps are taking, kind of the manager base decline in the Permian. You had a pretty skinny sequential decline. In addition to new drilling activity, what are you doing to manage that base?
componenttext: John, I was wondering if you could perhaps comment on some of the steps are taking, kind of the manager base decline in the Permian. You had a pretty skinny sequential decline. In addition to new drilling activity, what are you doing to manage that base?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think one of the big things is we've stepped back, we've gone from trying to bring on a lot of wells and completing a lot of wells to really getting back to managing your base. And looking at fluid levels, looking at optimizing how we're producing
componenttext: Well, I think one of the big things is we've stepped back, we've gone from trying to bring on a lot of wells and completing a lot of wells to really getting back to managing your base. And looking at fluid levels, looking at optimizing how we're producing these wells, changing some of the lift, it's amazing what you can do when you take the time. Compression, optimizing water shut offs, little things. And there's not a lot of money. But more sure makes a big, big difference. I mean, we got back in, cleaned out some injectors and some of water floods. just some of the old bread and butter classic Apache things that we've done for decades.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I remember you commenting maybe in a previous call that you thought that your overall base decline rate was in the low 20% range. Any thoughts on that number? Is it coming down?
componenttext: John, I remember you commenting maybe in a previous call that you thought that your overall base decline rate was in the low 20% range. Any thoughts on that number? Is it coming down?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, clearly, as we started the year, we said it was in the mid -- 25%, 26% range. As we bring on fewer wells, which is what we've done, it has flattened and it's flattening. That's a good topic of discussion with reservoir engineers because we'r
componenttext: Well, I mean, clearly, as we started the year, we said it was in the mid -- 25%, 26% range. As we bring on fewer wells, which is what we've done, it has flattened and it's flattening. That's a good topic of discussion with reservoir engineers because we're always working on that. But clearly, it is coming off, and clearly, in terms of flattening and then also all these sell to. So I think you'll see us continue to focus on that. It gets back to the quality of having some conventional, a big chunk of our Permian, as water floods and CO2 floods, and things that just don't decline rapidly. There's a lot of things you can do, scale, cleanouts, all kinds of things, moving more water, which is a lot more option to pull on your conventional asset base and you're seeing us pull those, so I think you'll see it flatten.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Scott Hanold with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Scott Hanold with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just specifically on some North Sea activity. Did the storm [indiscernible] wells? Did those move into this year? And if you could comment if changes in the PRT tax over there have changed your view on how active you get.
componenttext: Just specifically on some North Sea activity. Did the storm [indiscernible] wells? Did those move into this year? And if you could comment if changes in the PRT tax over there have changed your view on how active you get.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say that the change in the PRC are very helpful. It does not change where we are in terms of the game plan. I mean, we got such a low-cost structure there relative to the rest of the industry. And we're going to generate cash flow in the North Sea, mu
componenttext: I'd say that the change in the PRC are very helpful. It does not change where we are in terms of the game plan. I mean, we got such a low-cost structure there relative to the rest of the industry. And we're going to generate cash flow in the North Sea, much like Egypt on our international portfolio. So it does not change big picture the step for taking. But it does make things more attractive, it provides us incremental cash flow. And let's do a few more things. We do plan to bring store in con into the back half of this year at this point. So that will be the plan will be to at least get the wells drilled back half of the year or could spill into next year.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks. And as my follow up, turning to the Permian. Really good results on that Seagull wells. Can you give a little color on what you all might have done differently there? And maybe a little bit of color to on that, I guess, new zone within the T
componenttext: Okay, thanks. And as my follow up, turning to the Permian. Really good results on that Seagull wells. Can you give a little color on what you all might have done differently there? And maybe a little bit of color to on that, I guess, new zone within the Third Bone Spring that you're looking at?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean Seagull is a pretty -- it's only a 4,600-foot lateral, it's really target testing. And modification, I mean, as we continue to understand hydrocarbon system, we're figuring out exactly where to land of those wells and how to modify our fracs.
componenttext: Well, I mean Seagull is a pretty -- it's only a 4,600-foot lateral, it's really target testing. And modification, I mean, as we continue to understand hydrocarbon system, we're figuring out exactly where to land of those wells and how to modify our fracs. And Tim, do you have any color you want to add?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, really the results of the Seagull well incorporates the integration of that team, and it really takes into consideration the 3D and targeting fracture intensity here. And it's had tremendous results. And I think is repeatable as we've just recently p
componenttext: Yes, really the results of the Seagull well incorporates the integration of that team, and it really takes into consideration the 3D and targeting fracture intensity here. And it's had tremendous results. And I think is repeatable as we've just recently put a well online, our Bluejay 103, it's flowing over 2,000 barrels of oil per day. A very similar geologic environment.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of Doug Leggate with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of Doug Leggate with Bank of America.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Guys, I don't if you could give this or not. But Egypt and the North Sea are your big cash carriers in the portfolio. I wonder if you could give us an idea of what the operating cash and free cash flow those assets this quarter?
componenttext: Guys, I don't if you could give this or not. But Egypt and the North Sea are your big cash carriers in the portfolio. I wonder if you could give us an idea of what the operating cash and free cash flow those assets this quarter?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug, we typically don't give that type of information down to the asset level. You obviously can figure that out at the end of each year. We are thinking about some potentially expanding our -- both our guidance and our detailed reporting around thi
componenttext: Yes, Doug, we typically don't give that type of information down to the asset level. You obviously can figure that out at the end of each year. We are thinking about some potentially expanding our -- both our guidance and our detailed reporting around things like that for the future, but we're not ready to start doing that at this point in time. I can tell you that both of those assets areas this year will be cash flow generators for us.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Will the free cash flow positive in Q1?
componenttext: Will the free cash flow positive in Q1?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to say whether if they were or not. I could say that they will be for the year, that's for sure.
componenttext: I'm not going to say whether if they were or not. I could say that they will be for the year, that's for sure.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Freeman with Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Freeman with Raymond James.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the Bluejay 103 H that you just mentioned, you came out over 2,000 barrels a day and also set a record and completed 3.5 million. What were the specs from that wells? Just like the lateral lengths?
componenttext: On the Bluejay 103 H that you just mentioned, you came out over 2,000 barrels a day and also set a record and completed 3.5 million. What were the specs from that wells? Just like the lateral lengths?

componenttext: That's just a single mile lateral.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then where specifically is it located in your position?
componenttext: And then where specifically is it located in your position?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's our target 1 in the 3rd Bone Spring center.
componenttext: It's our target 1 in the 3rd Bone Spring center.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Sankey with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Sankey with Wolfe Research.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to keep going on the Bluejay and the Seagull if I could. But if you put in the wider context, you talked about design and efficiency gaining you in cost considerably since 2014. Has there been a step change there or is that a linear progression?
componenttext: I'm going to keep going on the Bluejay and the Seagull if I could. But if you put in the wider context, you talked about design and efficiency gaining you in cost considerably since 2014. Has there been a step change there or is that a linear progression? And further to that, you mentioned the results of the Bluejay very strong. I was going to ask you if they were less than the Seagull where you have a strong volume performance? Can we go, I guess, what I'm driving out with the linear and the step is can we actually go a whole lot lower than that 3.5 million? Does it have a similar split between drilling and completion that we typically see? How much more do you think we can get out for less money? It's a question of more volume or can you actually even go less money?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, when you look at -- we put in a good supplement a good bar chart that showed the steps in terms of how the cost have come down really over the last 5 or 6 quarters. So I continue to be amazed at what we can do. Obviously, there are certain things
componenttext: I mean, when you look at -- we put in a good supplement a good bar chart that showed the steps in terms of how the cost have come down really over the last 5 or 6 quarters. So I continue to be amazed at what we can do. Obviously, there are certain things that as you get lower and lower, it gets harder to keep having more source of production. I think $3.5 million for a mile-long lateral in the Delaware is pretty strong, especially with the type of productivity the wells come on and tell us you we're not cutting corners on the competition or anything like that. So we're clearly keep driving. I mean, the guys would tell you they can keep taking off small chunks. But how far -- how much further can we go, I think it'll be a function -- we'll just have to wait and see what we can do. In terms of performance, it's going to end up being pretty similar to the Seagull. The 2,800 BOEs a day included gas, the 2,000 that Tim referenced very early on the Bluejay, and that's just on the oil side. I think it's going to be a pretty similar well before it's all said and done, but we'll have to wait and see.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to go back to the question of the possible acceleration in the back half '16. I know you spent a lot of your prepared comments on this and you already have a couple questions in the Q&A here. But a number of other companies have spoken about this
componenttext: I'd like to go back to the question of the possible acceleration in the back half '16. I know you spent a lot of your prepared comments on this and you already have a couple questions in the Q&A here. But a number of other companies have spoken about this decision as kind of the maybe being of 2 pieces. The first question is, do you have the capacity to accelerate? And then the second would be, do you have the appetite or do you have the returns to? And I wonder if you could speak more to that second piece. I understand you want to use stay cash flow neutral in the year. But in this current environment, is $45 enough for -- do you have cash flow, but is it enough on the returns front on this place to really entice you to up your rig count?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, a couple of things. Number one, we've seen tremendous progress. And that, we've got a lot of wells returns actually, full cycle, fully burdened. Look pretty darn good. So I think we've got plenty of inventory. If you go back a year ago, everybody st
componenttext: John, a couple of things. Number one, we've seen tremendous progress. And that, we've got a lot of wells returns actually, full cycle, fully burdened. Look pretty darn good. So I think we've got plenty of inventory. If you go back a year ago, everybody started ramping up and adding rigs quickly, and expecting prices to hold. And unfortunately, those that have spent significantly in anticipation of what I'll call visibility in the more flat, the longer sustainable price environment ended up having to go back to the debt markets, to the equity markets, that sort of things. So we're good to be cautious, we're going to be very thoughtful and disciplined. And like I said, we're going to want to see some cash flow accrue before we start putting things back to work. And we'll have a lot of conversations over the next couple months and weeks, actually starting next week with the board. A lot to talk about. And the nice thing is we have a lot of attractive options right now. We've also got a lot of things we want to test. And quite frankly, as I look at the results, I look at the well cost, I'm glad I didn't announce spend in some of the quarters, because we've got wells that we didn't drill. I mean, we continue to make progress, we'll do things differently. So there's a fine line of feeling when we're ready to move forward. We clearly have the financial capacity to do so. The returns are starting to look pretty darn good. I mean it's a function of managing and balancing your financial structure.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful details. Am I understanding you correctly that it's not just the level of the oil price that you want to see, you want to see it settle in there with less volatility. Am I...
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful details. Am I understanding you correctly that it's not just the level of the oil price that you want to see, you want to see it settle in there with less volatility. Am I...

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're going to have to be prepared to live in volatile brand. So -- but I just want to say more visibility into more belief we're going to have the cash flow that's going to come with the price, and it's going to stay there a little bit. So.
componenttext: We're going to have to be prepared to live in volatile brand. So -- but I just want to say more visibility into more belief we're going to have the cash flow that's going to come with the price, and it's going to stay there a little bit. So.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from the line of the Michael Hall with Heikkinen Energy Advisers.
componenttext: Your next question will come from the line of the Michael Hall with Heikkinen Energy Advisers.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just couple of kind of accounting related questions for me. First, on Egypt, am I understanding it right, you basically had, on a recurring net income basis, about a $17 million loss if I just back off the $54 [ph] million write-down from $71 million nonc
componenttext: Just couple of kind of accounting related questions for me. First, on Egypt, am I understanding it right, you basically had, on a recurring net income basis, about a $17 million loss if I just back off the $54 [ph] million write-down from $71 million noncontrolling interest? I'm just talking about the noncontrolling interest in that $17 million. And if that's right, I'm just trying to think through, what price level is that business net income breakeven?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sorry, Michael, we're looking at -- what number for Egypt?
componenttext: Yes, sorry, Michael, we're looking at -- what number for Egypt?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: On then noncontrolling interest side, the $71 million loss that was backed out. If could you just adjust that for $54 million write-down in the adjustment, you had a $17 million loss on that 1/3 of the business. Is that the right way to think about it? An
componenttext: On then noncontrolling interest side, the $71 million loss that was backed out. If could you just adjust that for $54 million write-down in the adjustment, you had a $17 million loss on that 1/3 of the business. Is that the right way to think about it? And if so, what price level brings net income to breakeven?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. So I think that for the quarter, yes, that's a reasonable way to think about that. Because when you reduce operating results down to like single quarter, you're going to get lots of noise in that quarter. So for example, I think we have a signi
componenttext: Yes, okay. So I think that for the quarter, yes, that's a reasonable way to think about that. Because when you reduce operating results down to like single quarter, you're going to get lots of noise in that quarter. So for example, I think we have a significant piece of noise on the revenue side in Egypt for the quarter to the tune of about $8 million on gas revenue side that were some dispute we're looking at. I think that's obviously, the issue with the price that would breakeven, so how much lower can the price go, either breakeven from an accounting perspective, I think that's obviously very difficult to do because of the cost-sharing arrangement in the PSC. So I'm not really prepared to say how far down prices would have to go in order for that number to become 0. But suffice it to say, we had to go down a bit more from where it is in the first quarter in order for that to happen.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, kind of -- that's I'll go more off-line. The other piece is just on the North Sea. Again, kind of accounting related. But $27 million PRT refund, was that adjusted on a net income in that $55 million tax adjustment? Or is that still into the income l
componenttext: Yes, kind of -- that's I'll go more off-line. The other piece is just on the North Sea. Again, kind of accounting related. But $27 million PRT refund, was that adjusted on a net income in that $55 million tax adjustment? Or is that still into the income line? Is that expected to recur or is that -- any more of those coming this year?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So no, it's not adjusted out of net income. It is a PRT refund because of some cost related to prior year items. That's not an unusual type of thing to happen in the North Sea. We have that happen on a regular basis. We never adjust that out either it's a
componenttext: So no, it's not adjusted out of net income. It is a PRT refund because of some cost related to prior year items. That's not an unusual type of thing to happen in the North Sea. We have that happen on a regular basis. We never adjust that out either it's a benefit to us or a detriment to us. We don't adjust that out for calculating adjusted earnings or adjusted EBITDA. It's a large item this quarter relative to typical PRT simply because PRT is now approaching 0 with the pricing environment that we have. It's not -- if you go back 2 or 3 years, you'll find PRT expensive, nearly $300 million in some years.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question I have is on cash flow. You highlighted in your prepared remarks there was a big swing in working capital during the first quarter as well as an excess of cash CapEx over accrual CapEx. So just to confirm, we should expect those items to re
componenttext: First question I have is on cash flow. You highlighted in your prepared remarks there was a big swing in working capital during the first quarter as well as an excess of cash CapEx over accrual CapEx. So just to confirm, we should expect those items to reverse throughout the year so that you don't have any net debt additions, kind of all else equal according to budget?

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right. So if we assume we don't pay down any debt this year, we expect to end this closer to the $1.5 billion of cash where we started. We had about a little over $450 million of cash consumption in the first quarter. Roughly 2/3 of that, if you ju
componenttext: That's right. So if we assume we don't pay down any debt this year, we expect to end this closer to the $1.5 billion of cash where we started. We had about a little over $450 million of cash consumption in the first quarter. Roughly 2/3 of that, if you just take -- if you look at first quarter actual versus the plan that it would take for the year to get to cash flow neutrality. Of that $450 million, about 2/3 of that is because we built working capital in the first quarter. And we had practically in 0 sale proceeds in the first quarter. We expect both of those items to be cash flow generators for us by the time we get to the end of the year. So about 2/3 of the $450 million is simply because of that. We have a pretty significant build in working capital during the quarter. The other 1/3 of the $450 million would be split roughly 50-50 between the overspending capital in the year versus kind of an average quarterly run rate for the year, and the shortfall on revenues less OpEx because of the fact that prices were below our $35 2 35 [ph] Henry Hub plan for the year. On the working capital side. I mean, so we built working capital in the first quarter? The primary reason for that is because of the paydown of payables and accrued cost between the end of the fourth quarter last year and the end of first quarter this year. And that's primarily because activity is slowing down so much, so our payables are coming down. Activity won't continue to slow down quite at a pace that it did through the time frame. And we expect inventory and accounts receivables, which tends to lag a bit the paydown the payables, those also come down through the year. And then we've got some pretty significant unique items, if you will, on the working capital side that we expect late this year, probably in the fourth quarter. Those are primarily in the form of tax refunds on loss carry backs that one has been filed, one is about to be filed. And then also we do anticipate some asset sales, which will also take place later this year, the proceeds of which will come late in 2015. So all of those things combined to offset the $460 million cash deficit that we incurred in the first quarter. A  very long winded way of saying yes, with anticipate getting back to $1.5 billion cash with the same debt level by the end of this year.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks for the clarity there. And my second question or follow-up is, you talked about adding capital potentially back to the Permian first, if you got some stability on the oil price and felt good about the cost structure. But I guess, I was wonde
componenttext: Great, thanks for the clarity there. And my second question or follow-up is, you talked about adding capital potentially back to the Permian first, if you got some stability on the oil price and felt good about the cost structure. But I guess, I was wondering, you all are comfortable allocating that towards strategic testing first, kind of like you're already doing this year, rather than full development or more development drilling. Just kind of curious how you have the capital efficiency between strategic testing and development drilling.

headline: Apache Corp., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and Michael, in my prepared comments, we said, obviously, there will be some that were in the development side of the Permian as well as some acceleration on some of the testing. And then also you've got couple of platform rigs in the North Sea that
componenttext: Yes, and Michael, in my prepared comments, we said, obviously, there will be some that were in the development side of the Permian as well as some acceleration on some of the testing. And then also you've got couple of platform rigs in the North Sea that we'd like to keep active, and then you got each of the projects in Egypt as well as the Woodford. So we look at what sets us up best for the future, and we look at the timing under which we want to go drill some development wells as well. So it will be a balance, but did see some of them going to development potential and then some other would accelerate some testing.
